channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Pentagon Official Heads to Israel Amid Fears of Iranian Attack
item.description: U.S. officials have said they are bracing for a response to an Israeli strike in Syria this month that killed several senior Iranian commanders.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Julian Assange’s Family React to Biden Suggesting U.S. Might Drop Case
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder has spent five years in a high-security London prison while contesting extradition efforts. Before that, he holed up for seven years in the Ecuadorean Embassy.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Julian Assange leaving a London court in a prison van in 2019. He has been asking Britain’s courts to prevent his extradition to the United States.

item.title: Mexico’s 2024 General Election: What to Know
item.description: Mexico’s election will make history. It will be the largest in terms of voters and seats, and the country will elect a female president for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

item.title: What the Election Loss Means for President Yoon of South Korea
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol, a key U.S. ally, faces the prospect of becoming a lame duck unless he starts negotiating with the opposition.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea casting his early vote for the parliamentary election, in Busan, this month. Voters delivered a decisive defeat for his party.

item.title: Ukraine’s New Draft Unsettles the Young
item.description: Reporters from The New York Times spoke to men who could be affected by the change.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder, Yurii Shyvala and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scrolly Text Slide 2

item.title: Before He Died in Prison, Aleksei Navalny Wrote a Memoir. It’s Coming This Fall.
item.description: In the book, Navalny tells his story in his own words, chronicling his life, his rise as an opposition leader, and the attempts on his life.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexei Navalny in 2013. Knopf will publish his posthumous memoir, “Patriot,” in October.

item.title: Ukraine’s Parliament Passes a Politically Fraught Mobilization Bill
item.description: The legislature approved a law aimed at replenishing depleted Ukrainian forces. Lawmakers said the bill included incentives for volunteers and new penalties for those trying to evade conscription.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian military recruits training in Kyiv in October.

item.title: World Central Kitchen Let Him Serve Gaza. He Paid With His Life.
item.description: The killing of foreign aid workers from World Central Kitchen brought international outrage. The death of their Palestinian driver drew less attention.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Bilal Shbair
item.media:description: Relatives and friends carrying the body of Saifeddin Abutaha, an aid worker for World Central Kitchen in Gaza, during his funeral last week in Rafah.

item.title: In Latin America, From Nasty Personal Insults to an Embassy Raid
item.description: Ecuador’s raid of Mexico’s embassy shows how foreign policy is often driven by personal politics, not national interest.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Natalie Kitroeff and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Police and military officials outside the Mexican Embassy on Friday in Quito, Ecuador, where they forcibly removed a former Ecuadorean vice president, Jorge Glas.

item.title: Biden Says U.S. Is Considering Dropping Assange Case
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder has been held in London as he has battled extradition to the United States on charges related to his publication of classified documents.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julian Assange in London in 2011. He has been jailed for nearly five years after being indicted by the United States with 18 counts of violating the Espionage Act.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Will Run Again in South Africa’s Presidential Election
item.description: The 81-year-old former leader has been cleared to appear on the ballot as an opposition candidate in May’s parliamentary election. Unless the decision is reversed, he could become a kingmaker — or even president once again.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Spear of the Nation (MK) (South African Political Party)
item.media:description: Former South African President Jacob Zuma, in blue, at an event near Cape Town, last month. He has broken with the governing African National Congress, and is heading a new political party.

item.title: What a Terror Attack in Israel Might Reveal About Psychedelics and Trauma
item.description: Thousands of Israelis were using mind-altering substances when Hamas-led fighters attacked a desert festival on Oct. 7. Now, scientists are studying the ravers to determine the effects of such drugs at a moment of extreme trauma.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer, Aaron Boxerman and Gal Koplewitz
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: This photo of Yuval Tapuhi was taken at the Tribe of Nova festival on Oct. 7, before the Hamas-led terrorist attack.

item.title: E.U. Migration Overhaul Clears Final Hurdle
item.description: Years in the making, the legislation is intended to update migration policy and cool anti-migrant sentiments ahead of E.U. elections in June.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Members of the European Parliament voting on the migration overhaul in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: The Push for a Better Dengue Vaccine Grows More Urgent
item.description: A public research institute in Brazil has proved a new shot protects against the disease, but can’t make it fast enough to stop the huge outbreak sweeping Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A nurse attends to a patient suffering from dengue at Chulucanas Hospital in Chulucanas, Peru in February.

item.title: Global Stockpile of Cholera Vaccine Is Gone as Outbreaks Spread
item.description: One company is going to great lengths to build it up, but it will be years before it returns to the minimum level.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A health worker administering a dosage of the cholera vaccine during an immunization campaign in Harare, Zimbabwe, in January.

item.title: Deborah Feldman, the Author of ‘Unorthodox,’ Touches a Nerve in Germany
item.description: Feldman, who wrote in “Unorthodox” about leaving her Hasidic community in New York, has been touching a nerve in Germany, where she is now a citizen.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.media:credit: Andrew White for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author Deborah Feldman has been outspoken about German politics since the beginning of the Israel-Hamas war.

item.title: 3 Men Rescued from Pacific Island After Writing ‘Help’ With Palm Leaves
item.description: American rescuers found the lost sailors on a tiny uninhabited island in Micronesia with a damaged boat and the word spelled out on the beach.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: In this image provided by the U.S. Coast Guard, the word “help” is written in palm fronds on the beach of a small island in Micronesia.

item.title: European Central Bank Signals Coming Rate Cut, Setting Up Split With Fed
item.description: The bank held rates for the fifth consecutive time, but said confidence was growing that inflation would return to its target and it could ease its stance soon.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: The European Central Bank, its headquarters in Frankfurt, has been trying to work out the delicate timing of when to cut interest rates.

item.title: Israel Announces New Attack on Hamas After Killing Top Leader’s Sons
item.description: The military said it had carried out an operation in Gaza to kill members of Hamas, a day after attacking a car carrying three sons of Ismail Haniyeh, the group’s political leader.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh during a visit to Tehran last month.

item.title: Vietnamese Real Estate Tycoon Sentenced to Death in $12 Billion Fraud Case
item.description: Truong My Lan received the death penalty as Vietnam’s Communist Party cracks down on corruption in the fast-growing Southeast Asian economic hub.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Chau Doan
item.media:description: Truong My Lan during her trial in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, on Thursday.

item.title: In Warning to China, Biden Hosts Summit With Leaders of Japan and Philippines
item.description: President Biden has invited the leaders of Japan and the Philippines to the White House, where they will discuss security in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden hosted Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan at the White House on Wednesday and announced measures to foster greater military cooperation with Japan.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Japan’s prime minister visits the White House.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden and first lady Dr. Jill Biden greeted Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Mrs. Yuko Kishida of Japan.

item.title: Akebono, Hawaii-Born Sumo Champion in Japan, Dies at 54
item.description: Born in Hawaii, he moved to Japan in 1988 and won 11 grand championships. His success drove a resurgence in the sport’s popularity.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim, Hisako Ueno and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The sumo wrestler Akebono at a ceremony in Japan in 1998.

item.title: Driven by China, Coal Plants Made a Comeback in 2023
item.description: The country, along with India, is still building power stations that run on coal. Elsewhere, retirements of older plants have slowed.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: The coal terminal at the port in Lianyungang, China, in December.

item.title: Hamas Does Not Have 40 Hostages Who Meet Terms of Potential Swap With Israel, Official Says
item.description: The claim raised fears that more hostages may be dead than previously believed.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally on Sunday in Jerusalem calling for the release of the remaining hostages as the war in Gaza reached the six-month mark.

item.title: Hamas Leader Ismail Haniyeh Defiant After Israeli Strike Kills 3 of His Sons
item.description: Israel confirmed the killing of the sons of the Hamas political leader, Ismail Haniyeh, and said all three were Hamas military operatives.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: The car in which three sons of the Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh were reportedly killed during an Israeli strike in Al-Shati camp, west of Gaza City, on Wednesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Japan’s Leader Visits Washington
item.description: Also, South Korean exit polls suggest a defeat for the president’s party.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Fumio Kishida celebrated the U.S.-Japan relationship.

item.title: Biden Says Israel Has Improved Aid Flow to Gaza but Must Do More
item.description: Mr. Biden said he was “blunt and straightforward” with Israel’s leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, but declined to say explicitly whether he would condition future U.S. arms shipments on the response.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said that Israel had done more to provide aid but that he expected additional action.

item.title: Nijole Sadunaite, Lithuanian Nun Who Opposed Soviet Rule, Dies at 85
item.description: A dissident who promoted democracy and religious freedom, she was arrested by the K.G.B. After independence from Moscow, she was honored by Lithuania’s Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Death Toll Likely to Rise After Explosion at Hydroelectric Plant in Italy
item.description: Emergency workers were searching for four other workers who were missing after the blast in northern Italy, which has galvanized unions in the region.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The Enel hydroelectric power plant, after a fatal explosion and fire south of Bologna on Wednesday.

item.title: Floods in Russia and Kazakhstan Force Thousands to Evacuate
item.description: More than 100,000 people had to leave their homes after spring floods engulfed cities and villages in vast sections of neighboring countries.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Emergency workers near a flooded street in Orsk, Russia, on Monday after a dam burst on the Ural River, near Russia’s border with Kazakhstan.

item.title: Few Signs of Progress on Aid to Gaza After Israeli Pledges
item.description: Israel promised last week to open a border crossing and a port to aid shipments, but it is not clear when either change will occur. Israel and the U.N. also disagree on how much aid is reaching Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivian Yee and Lauren Leatherby
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Aid was unloaded at Kamal Adwan Hospital in northern Gaza on Saturday.

item.title: Hong Kong Detains and Expels Journalism Advocate, Group Says
item.description: A representative of Reporters Without Borders was attempting to monitor the national security trial of a media tycoon, Jimmy Lai.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Reporters outside the entrance to the Hong Kong court where Jimmy Lai began standing trial last year.

item.title: Ocean Heat Has Shattered Records for More Than a Year. What’s Happening?
item.description: There have been record temperatures every day for more than a year. Scientists are investigating what’s behind the extraordinary measurements.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa

item.title: A Reverse Art Heist? Museum Finds Employee’s Painting on Its Wall
item.description: The Pinakothek der Moderne in Munich said it had fired a worker for hanging one of his own pieces in its modern art collection.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pinakothek der Moderne in 2020. The museum said the worker had hung the painting when he was helping install an exhibition in the architecture section.

item.title: Which Countries Fund and Supply Israel’s Military?
item.description: Some governments that sell weapons to Israel — a list that is topped by the United States and Germany — are facing legal challenges and protests over those exports.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in Gaza last month.

item.title: Croatia 2024 General Election: What to Know
item.description: A snap general election has left the country’s governing party exposed to an unexpectedly strong challenge from populist forces.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins

item.title: Biden Says Netanyahu Is Making ‘a Mistake’ in Gaza
item.description: In an interview recorded last week, the president said again that an Israeli strike on aid workers in Gaza was an outrage.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s frustration over Israel’s conduct in the war has hit a peak in recent weeks, an administration official has said.

item.title: Roger, a Rescue Dog, Becomes Taiwan Earthquake Hero
item.description: The 8-year-old rescue dog, who was once deemed too friendly to sniff out drugs, found the body of the earthquake’s 13th victim.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Laurent Fievet/Hualien County Fire Department, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Da Vinci’s Been Dead for 500 Years. Who Gets to Profit from His Work?
item.description: Italian officials and a German puzzle maker are battling over a 1,000-piece puzzle bearing the image of the artist’s “Vitruvian Man.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Tourism (Italy)

item.title: Trudeau to Testify in Foreign Election Interference Inquiry
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau testified that past elections had been “free and fair,” but intelligence reports said meddling by China was “sophisticated” and “pervasive.”
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada testified on Wednesday at a public hearing of a foreign interference inquiry in Ottawa, the capital.

item.title: Why Xi Jinping is Meeting Ma Ying-jeou, Taiwan’s Ex-President
item.description: China is using talks between its top leader and Ma Ying-jeou to signal a willingness to engage with Taiwan — but only on its terms.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Coverage of the meeting between Ma Ying-jeou, the former President of Taiwan, and Xi Jingping, China’s leader, in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Says Israel ‘Will Be Punished’ for Strike in Syria
item.description: The leadership of Iran has repeatedly vowed to avenge the deadly April 1 strike on an Iranian Embassy building in Damascus.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks carrying the coffins of seven Iranian commanders killed in an Israeli airstrike in Syria passed by mourners in Tehran on Friday.

item.title: Gazans Find Little to Celebrate as Eid al-Fitr Begins at the End of Ramadan
item.description: The holiday used to be a joyful time in Gaza. But with Israel’s military offensive and famine threatening the enclave, Palestinians there feel far from any sense of festivity.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda

item.title: As Speaker, Johnson Advances What He Once Opposed, Enraging the Right
item.description: Now that he is the leader, the Louisiana Republican has found himself bowing to governing realities that are now his problem.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson in Washington last month.

item.title: Paris F.C. Set Tickets To $0. Should Others Do the Same?
item.description: When Paris F.C. made its tickets free, it began an experiment into the connection between fans and teams, and posed a question about the value of big crowds to televised sports.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paris F.C. fans at the Stade Charléty, where attendance is up by more than a third this season.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A landmark climate ruling in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: The climate-related lawsuit against Switzerland was brought by a group of older women.

item.title: South Korean Election to Set Tone for Remainder of President’s Term
item.description: The vote on Wednesday was a big test for President Yoon Suk Yeol, who has forged closer ties with the United States and Japan but whose domestic agenda has stalled.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Casting a ballot in Seoul on Wednesday. The parliamentary election is seen as a referendum on President Yoon Suk Yeol.

item.title: Ancient Foxes Lived and Died With Humans
item.description: Extinct foxes and other animals were an important part of early South American communities, a new study has found.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: Germany Rebuffs Claim Its Arms Sales to Israel Abet Genocide in Gaza
item.description: Germany argued against the accusation brought by Nicaragua at the International Court of Justice, but Germans are questioning their country’s unwavering support for Israel.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons, Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli airstrike in the southern Gazan city of Khan Younis on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Divided South Korea Votes
item.description: Also, a landmark climate ruling in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: South Korea’s politics are more divided than ever.

item.title: David Cameron Reaches Out to Trump, Taking a Risk on His U.S. Trip
item.description: David Cameron, the British foreign secretary, said he spoke with Donald Trump, the former, and possibly future, president, about Ukraine and the Israel-Gaza conflict.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: The British foreign secretary, David Cameron, speaking during a joint news conference with the U.S. secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, at the State Department in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Austin Pushes Back on Claims of Israel Carrying Out Genocide in Gaza
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III made the comments during a hearing that was disrupted several times by protests of U.S. support for Israel’s assault on Hamas.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III testifying before a Senate committee on Tuesday.

item.title: When Is Eid This Year? How the Solar Eclipse Obscured Moon Sighting
item.description: Some Muslim communities rely on a centuries-old method to determine when Ramadan ends: a crescent moon. That method was harder to follow this year.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Indonesian Muslims in Gresik, Java, use a telescope to see the new crescent moon and determine the end of Ramadan.

item.title: Mount Etna Spews Volcanic Vortex Rings Into Italy’s Sky
item.description: The volcano, one of Europe’s most active, has been spewing volcanic vortex rings at a rapid pace. But that doesn’t mean a big explosion is on the way, one expert says.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo

item.title: Champions League: Security Increased After ISIS Threats
item.description: Online messages urged violent attacks on four matches, prompting the police in England, France and Spain to step up precautions.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden, Rachel Chaundler and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Police officers and fans in Madrid, where Real Madrid will play Manchester City in a Champions League quarterfinal on Tuesday.

item.title: Turkey Restricts Exports to Israel in Protest of War in Gaza
item.description: Turkey announced limits on dozens of products, including cement and jet fuel, prompting Israel to threaten retaliatory trade measures.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cargo ship sailing in the Bosporus, seen from Istanbul.

item.title: On the International Booker Prize Shortlist, Heartbreak and Family Love
item.description: Books by Jenny Erpenbeck and Hwang Sok-yong are among six nominees for the prestigious award for translated fiction.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Xi of China Meets With Russia’s Foreign Minister, Reaffirming Ties
item.description: The visit came days after the U.S. threatened new sanctions against Chinese companies if they aided Russia’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Russian Foreign Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo released by the Russian Foreign Ministry of Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov in Beijing, where he also met with his Chinese counterpart.

item.title: Should Alcoholic Beverages Have Cancer Warning Labels?
item.description: Ireland will require them starting in 2026, and there are nascent efforts elsewhere to add more explicit labeling about the health risks of drinking.
item.dc:creator: Ted Alcorn
